title: Signs of Fatigue: Trump Faces Realities of Aging in Office
summary: President Trump has always used his stamina and energy as a political strength. But that image is getting harder for him to sustain.

title: Once Foes of Obamacare, Some Republicans Push to Protect It
summary: A small cadre of politically vulnerable Republicans in Congress is breaking with the party to push for the extension of health care tax credits for a program the G.O.P. reviles.

title: Doctor Critical of Vaccines Quietly Appointed as C.D.C.’s Second in Command
summary: During the Covid-19 pandemic, Dr. Ralph Lee Abraham promoted discredited treatments like ivermectin and, as Louisiana’s surgeon general, halted the state’s mass vaccination campaign.

title: Market Volatility Underscores Epic Buildup of Global Risk
summary: Some experts see a dangerous combination of factors reminiscent of practices that led to previous financial crises.

title: Russia Strikes Ukraine and Signals Resistance to Amended Peace Plan
summary: The attack killed at least seven people in Kyiv, the authorities said, as Moscow suggested it would resist changes negotiated by Ukraine.

title: Republicans Fight With Trump’s Team Over Ukraine Talks
summary: Senator Mitch McConnell and several other lawmakers have accused President Trump’s team of appeasing the Kremlin, warning that doing so would not lead to lasting peace.

title: Times Analysis Finds Errors in Trump’s Supreme Court Filing That Calls for National Guard in Chicago
summary: The Trump administration has claimed the police were slow to protect federal agents on Oct. 4, but videos and audio show that their rationale conflates hours of events involving a shooting, a protest, a car crash and a police radio call.

title: Vahid Abedini, University of Oklahoma Professor, Released After ICE Detainment
summary: Vahid Abedini, who colleagues said was in the United States on an H-1B visa, was arrested on his way to a conference in Washington. It was unclear why.

title: 100 Notable Books of 2025
summary: Here is the standout fiction and nonfiction of the year, selected by the staff of The New York Times Book Review.

title: An Eritrean Woman Seeking Asylum in Canada Was Almost Deported From the U.S.
summary: After more than 20 years in the U.S., an Eritrean mother and nurse tried to self-deport to Canada. She found herself in a Texas detention center instead.

title: Indiana Lawmakers Are Poised to Vote on Redistricting After All
summary: Republican leaders in the legislature backtracked and said they would vote on a new congressional map that President Trump wants, though support remained uncertain.

title: D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser Says She Won’t Run for a Fourth Term
summary: She has led the heavily Democratic city through confrontations with President Trump, who earlier this year sought to impose federal control over the local Police Department.

title: Boston Mayor Wu Question’s Mamdani’s Approach to Meeting With Trump
summary: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani won praise for his meeting with President Trump. But Michelle Wu, the like-minded mayor of Boston, said “flattery is not the way.”

title: Fears About A.I. Prompt Talks of Super PACs to Rein In the Industry
summary: As artificial intelligence companies prepare to pour money into the midterm elections, some in the A.I. world are hatching plans of their own to curb the industry’s influence.

title: How Much Will Thanksgiving Dinner Cost? It Depends on Whom You Ask.
summary: As Americans become increasingly concerned about affordability, there’s scrutiny on the annual meal.

title: Anxiety. It’s What’s for Thanksgiving Dinner.
summary: In a year of high prices, economic uncertainty and other jitters, America is united in uncertainty — and poultry.

title: Bolsonaro To Start Serving 27-Year Prison Sentence Over Coup Plot
summary: Brazil’s Supreme Court ordered former President Jair Bolsonaro to begin serving a prison term for conspiring to remain in power after losing the last election.

title: Prosecutors Prepare to Try Suspect in Etan Patz Case for the Third Time
summary: The defendant, Pedro Hernandez, was convicted in 2017 of kidnapping the 6-year-old, who disappeared in 1979 in SoHo.

title: Will Dressing Up Fix Flying?
summary: Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy has introduced a campaign meant to encourage civility.

title: Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy Wants Healthier In-Flight Snack Options
summary: Sean Duffy, who has been promoting greater decorum among air travelers, said he would like to see choices besides salty pretzels and buttery cookies.

title: The ‘New’ Solution for the N.Y.C. Housing Crisis: Single-Room Apartments
summary: There is a push to revive single-room occupancy housing, where kitchens and bathrooms are shared among apartments as small as 100 square feet each.

title: New York Leads Effort to Stop Plan That Could Cut Housing for 170,000
summary: The Trump administration is pushing a new approach to America’s homeless crisis, favoring shelters and rehabilitation centers over long-term housing for people who use drugs and alcohol.

title: Mapping the Brain’s Sense of What Goes On Inside the Body
summary: Scientists are learning how the brain knows what’s happening throughout the body, and how that process might go awry in some psychiatric disorders.

title: How New York Can Protect Its Street Vendors
summary: The city’s history can be understood through the people who sell food on sidewalks. Here’s how New York could set them up for success.

summary: An opportunity for families and friends and, by extension, communities, states, and the country itself to have a national reset.

title: Violence Is Driving Catastrophic Hunger in Nigeria, U.N. Report Says
summary: Africa’s most populous nation was already facing one of the world’s biggest hunger crises. It’s getting much worse.

title: Joan Branson, Richard Branson’s Wife of 35 Years, Dies at 80
summary: Mr. Branson, the Virgin Atlantic founder, announced her death in an Instagram post.

title: Penny Oleksiak, Canadian Swimmer, Faces 2-Year Ban Over Antidoping Testing Rules
summary: Penny Oleksiak, 25, who has won seven Olympic medals, was sanctioned under antidoping rules. Her suspension ends before the 2028 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: Postpartum Prescription of GLP-1 Drugs Has Increased Sharply, Study Finds
summary: By mid-2024, the weight-loss drugs were prescribed for almost 2 percent of new mothers.
